  physical_appearance: The image shows a rectangular colour photograph. The surrounding frame has patterns all over its body. The photograph depicts a Peranakan wedding. It features a four people
 comprising of a man
 a woman
 and two children. The adults are standing in the middle
 separating the two children. All of them are dressed in the Peranakan ethnic costumes and have makeup on. They are standing on a carpet
 in the interior of a building. The surrounding consists of potted plants
 photographic frames
 and furniture.

  subject_terms_1: weddings (ceremonies) ethnic groups Peranakan studio portraits children (people by age group) group portraits

  subject_terms_2: Colour photography Weddings Peranakan (Asian people) Children Portraits
 Group Portrait photography

  subject_terms_3: Children Heritage and Culture Portrait photography Marriage customs

  sgcool_label_text: This photograph shows a Peranakan bride and groom in an interior of a house
 accompanied by a pageboy and bridesmaid.  \r\n\r\nPhotographs were sometimes painted
 usually by an artist who first applied Chinese ink or oil paint to the negative before further working on the print. With the advent of colour negative film in the 1950s
 hand-tinted photographs fell out of vogue.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image shows a rectangular colour photograph. The surrounding frame has patterns all over its body. The photograph depicts a Peranakan wedding. It features a four people, comprising of a man, a woman, and two children. The adults are standing in the middle, separating the two children. All of them are dressed in the Peranakan ethnic costumes and have makeup on. They are standing on a carpet, in the interior of a building. The surrounding consists of potted plants, photographic frames, and furniture.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This photograph shows a Peranakan bride and groom in an interior of a house, accompanied by a pageboy and bridesmaid.  

Photographs were sometimes painted, usually by an artist who first applied Chinese ink or oil paint to the negative before further working on the print. With the advent of colour negative film in the 1950s, hand-tinted photographs fell out of vogue.
